questions.q: What is the primary goal of Systems Analysis and Design?
options: To develop application software that supports organizational functions
questions.explanation: The main goal of Systems analysis and design is developing application software to support the organisation function.

questions.q: According to the document, which of the following is an example of application software?
questions.explanation: Application Software is software designed to process data in an organisation to help users. Examples are spreadsheets, word processor and DBMS.

questions.q: Which characteristic of a system is defined as the point of contact with its environment?
questions.explanation: Interfaces are defined as the point of contact with the environment.

questions.q: The process of breaking a large system into smaller, more manageable parts is known as:
questions.explanation: Decomposition is the process of breaking the system into smaller components.

questions.q: What is the focus of modularity in system design?
options: Breaking the system into smaller parts
Organizing the parts into independent modules and defining their interaction
Measuring how focused a module is on a single task
questions.explanation: Modularity involves dividing the system into chunks or modules for easier management.

questions.q: Which design characteristic indicates how dependent one module is on another?
questions.explanation: Coupling determines to what extent the subsystems are dependent on each other.

questions.q: What is the desired quality for a well-designed software system regarding coupling and cohesion?
questions.explanation: While not explicitly spelled out in the slides, it is a foundational software engineering principle that modules should be highly independent (low coupling) and highly focused (high cohesion). Coupling evaluates dependency , while cohesion evaluates if a subsystem performs a single function.

questions.q: A module that performs many unrelated tasks is an example of:
questions.explanation: Cohesion refers to what extent a subsystem performs a single function; performing many unrelated tasks indicates low cohesion.

questions.q: What is a System Development Methodology?
options: The physical hardware used to build a system
A standard process followed by an organization to develop an information system
A programming language used for development
The final report delivered to the client
questions.explanation: System Development Methodology is a standard process followed by an organisation to analyse, design, implement and maintain IS.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT listed as a system development methodology in the document?
questions.explanation: Prototyping is explicitly listed as an alternative methodology. The others are standard methodologies not explicitly mentioned in the provided text.

questions.q: What is the main output of the Systems Planning and Selection phase?
questions.explanation: The outputs for Systems Planning and Selection include a detailed work plan for the selected project.

questions.q: During which phase are technical, economic, and operational feasibility studied?
questions.explanation: A feasibility study to determine the economic and organisational impact is conducted during Systems Planning and Selection.

questions.q: What is the primary activity in the Systems Analysis phase?
questions.explanation: During Systems Analysis, the current system is studied and a proposed replacement system is presented.

questions.q: The Software Requirements Specification (SRS) is the main output of which phase?
questions.explanation: The output of the analysis phase is a description of the alternative solution proposed by the analysis team.

questions.q: What role does a System Analyst primarily serve?
options: The project manager who allocates resources
The lead programmer who writes the most complex code
The link or bridge between the business side (users) and the technical side (developers)
The quality assurance specialist who tests the final product
questions.explanation: The system analyst helps system users and managers specify their needs for improving existing systems or creating new ones.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a required skill for a systems analyst?
questions.explanation: While technical skills require understanding the capabilities and limitations of IT (including programming), "advanced programming in multiple languages" is not explicitly listed.

questions.q: What is the main output of the Systems Design phase?
options: The final software with all features
questions.explanation: The main output of the Systems Design phase includes detailed specifications of all system elements.

questions.q: The final phase of the SDLC, which includes writing code, testing, and maintenance, is called:
questions.explanation: The final phase is Phase 4: Systems Implementation and Maintenance.

questions.q: Which activity in the final phase involves verifying that the system works correctly?
questions.explanation: During the final phase, the system is coded, tested, and installed in the organisation.

questions.q: What does 'system goes live' refer to?
options: The system is installed for users (Deployment)
questions.explanation: This refers to the system being installed in the organisation.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the maintenance step in the final phase?
options: To create the system design document
To fix bugs and add new features
questions.explanation: In the final phase, the information system is systematically improved.

questions.q: What does CASE stand for in the context of systems development?
questions.explanation: CASE stands for Computer-aided Software Engineering.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of a CASE tool?
questions.explanation: CASE tools include diagramming tools.

questions.q: CASE tools provide automated support for which part of systems development?
options: For some portions of systems development
questions.explanation: CASE tools provide automated support for some portions of systems development.

questions.q: In the student registration system example, which module would be responsible for handling fee payments?
questions.explanation: In the university system diagram, components typically include administration and accounting.

questions.q: A system's ______ is the limit on what the system can do.
questions.explanation: Constraints are the limit on what a system can do.

questions.q: According to the course outline, 'Managing the IS Project' is a topic covered in which part?
options: Part One: Foundations for Systems Development
Part Two: Systems Planning and Selection
questions.explanation: Managing the IS Project is covered under Part One: Foundations for Systems Development.

questions.q: Which phase of the SDLC directly follows 'Systems Design'?
options: There is no phase after design
questions.explanation: Phase 4, Systems Implementation and Maintenance, follows Phase 3, Systems Design.

questions.q: Understanding the organisation's objectives, structure, and processes is crucial for a systems analyst to:
options: Succeed in developing and maintaining an information system
questions.explanation: To succeed, the systems analyst has to understand the organisation objectives, structure, and processes.

questions.q: According to the document, what are the inputs and outputs considered as?
options: The main goal of the SDLC
questions.explanation: Inputs and Outputs are listed as characteristics of a system.

questions.q: Application software is designed to process data in an organization to help users, with examples including spreadsheets and word processors.
questions.explanation: Application Software is software designed to process data in an organisation to help users, and examples are spreadsheets and word processors.

questions.q: In system design, high coupling between modules is considered a sign of a good, well-structured design.
questions.explanation: Coupling measures to what extent the subsystems are dependent on each other; high dependency (high coupling) makes a system difficult to manage.

questions.q: The Systems Analysis phase focuses on defining how the system will be built, including its architecture and database design.
questions.explanation: Defining how a system will be built (hardware/software specifics) is part of the Logical and Physical Design in the Systems Design phase, not Systems Analysis.

questions.q: A systems analyst needs strong communication skills to effectively act as a link between users and technical developers.
questions.explanation: Interpersonal skills help the analyst in dealing with users and programmers.

questions.q: The Systems Implementation phase is concerned with identifying existing system problems and defining the project scope.
questions.explanation: Identifying problems and defining the scope is done in Phase 1: Systems Planning and Selection.

questions.q: Maintenance is an activity that only occurs after a system fails and is separate from the standard SDLC phases.
questions.explanation: Maintenance is a formal part of Phase 4: Systems Implementation and Maintenance, where the system is systematically improved.

questions.q: Modularity is the process of breaking a system down into smaller parts to help reduce complexity.
questions.explanation: Modularity is dividing the system into chunks or modules for easier management.

questions.q: Cohesion measures how focused a module is on performing a single, well-defined task.
questions.explanation: Cohesion determines to what extent a subsystem performs a single function.

questions.q: CASE tools can include diagramming tools, report generators, and code generators to support systems development.
questions.explanation: CASE tools include diagramming tools, computer display and report generators, documentation generators, and code generators.

questions.q: The environment of a system is one of its characteristics and includes all factors outside the system's boundary that can affect it.
questions.explanation: Environment is explicitly listed as one of the characteristics of a system.
